title: SB 1.18.49-50 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 01-05-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Mirandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chaksharunmilitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: Maharaj Parikshit's garlanding the sage with a dead snake was not at all a very serious offense, but Shringi's cursing the king was a serious offense.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces and explains verse 49, focusing on the incident of Parikshit Maharaj and the sage's son, emphasizing that Parikshit's action was a minor offense compared to the curse, and the boy's foolishness warranted pardon.

segments.key_quote: The curse was in no way an impediment for him to achieve the highest perfection. Rather it became a kind of boon in disguise.
segments.summary: The speaker continues explaining the situation of Maharaj Parikshit, highlighting how he didn't mind the curse and used it as an opportunity to achieve liberation through hearing the Srimad Bhagavatam from Shukadeva Goswami.

segments.key_quote: The whole series of events was a desire of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the events surrounding Parikshit Maharaj were part of the Lord's plan, using the analogy of Krishna using the Pandavas as instruments in the Kurukshetra war and Kala using instruments to bring about destruction.

segments.key_quote: So when everything is in relationship with Krishna nothing is bad, nothing is wrong, nothing is punishable.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verse 50, explaining that transcendentalists are not distressed or pleased by worldly things because they are transcendentally engaged.

segments.key_quote: Conditioned souls are always busy trying to avoid material distress and trying to maximize material happiness.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the behavior of conditioned souls, who seek material pleasure and avoid distress, with that of transcendentalists, who are indifferent to both.

segments.key_quote: The transcendentalists are of three kinds: The emperic philosophers, the mystics, and the devotees of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the three types of transcendentalists: jnanis, yogis, and bhaktas, and their respective goals of merging into the absolute, perceiving the Supersoul, and engaging in loving service to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: All categories of transcendentalists, their aim is the absolute truth only.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the three features of the Absolute Truth (Brahman, Paramatma, and Bhagavan) and how each type of transcendentalist aims for one of these features, emphasizing that they are all non-dual.

segments.key_quote: Parikshit Maharaj did not mind the cursing of that boy. Shamika Rishi did not mind Parikshit Maharaj insulting him. Both are transcendentalists.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by identifying Parikshit Maharaj as a devotee and Shamika Rishi as a mystic, explaining their detachment from the incident and reiterating that the child was an instrument of the Lord's will, ending the session with gratitude and Hare Krishna.
